Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 08:19PM StayShiny wrote: Lezza - good luck tomorrow! Woohoo for being done! Melrose - Yipee for being halfway done tomorrow! Good luck tomorrow! Jennyrdj - Yeah for the first one! The first few days are usually the easiest. Not sure if you took steroids but they help to keep you ramped up at first and then a crash. Day 3-7 were usually my worse with fatigue / flu like symptoms but you may beeeze through. Take meds at the first sign of nausea or pain. Keep on top of any other issues like constipation or diarrhea. Chemo causes this in many. Don't hesitate to ask here or call your MO's nurse if you have questions. Nails - I too have kept polish on my nails and cut short but not iced. No lifting or discoloring. Icing is not done by many at my place but it is permitted and certainly can't hurt. Neulasta - My MO does give the Neulasta shot after each to keep the WBC from dropping too low. I found Claritin starting the day before and @ 5 days after really helped with the bone pain...practically none. Hugs!

Janie - Sending positive thoughts for minimal throne time. For those that r having metal mouth or other taste issues, Rebecca Katz has a couple books and a website with recipes + suggestions. She uses the FASS rule - olive oil for fat, lemon juice for acid, sea salt and grade b maple syrup or agave nectar for sweet. For the metal taste she says to add a little sweet (syrup or nectar) + a squeeze of lemon. I have also read that using plastic utensils can help. For the scarf wearers, Goodwishes will give u a free scarf. Go to www.goodwishesscarves.org. I requested one last week. Can't wait to see how it is. Hugs!

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 03:30PM StayShiny wrote: Janie, glad you are starting to feel better and almost around that corner. I think everyone's body responds differently to this chemo. I had major "c" issues the first time but made adjustments and now have gotten that under control and only very slight "d" issues in the week post tx. Here is my drill. Day of tx, I take fruit and veggies to snack on during infusion along with a protein. Take a small dose of milk of magnesia for the next 3 days. I had this left over from surgery and my mo said if it worked for me, fine. Continue to eat fruit and veggies as long as they taste good. Breakfast is usually a bowl of oat bran with fresh chopped dates. Make my own blueberry, strawberry, raspberry, banana yogurt smoothie with whey protein most days. If I eat a low fiber food like mac + cheese or eggs, I try to have something with fiber with it. Such as steamed veggies or a high fiber English muffin. Some nights I just have rice and steamed veggies. I have little dairy other than the yogurt and maybe some cheese. I mostly drink water with lemon, some green tea and coffee, when it tastes ok. I do eat less for a week - 10 days after tx and snack more times a day. I'm not tying to eat less, I just either don't have the appetite or food doesn't taste right so I only eat a few bites. Hang in there. You'll be feeling better soon and moving into your "good" week. Hugs

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 11:24PM StayShiny wrote: Mary, way to go! Not easy but I think you will find it easier with time. Do you have a wig, hats or other head coverings? I have a wig bit find that I go without anything at home and mostly hats when I go out. Find what makes you feel comfortable. Jenny, I bring a bag packed with lunch, snacks, water. I may play words with friends, listen to music, read, watch a movie, etc. They have drinks, some snacks, internet and tvs at my place. The IV has battery back up so you can move around. I get up several times to use the restroom. If you sit the whole time you are not drinking enough. I drink 60 oz + when there. The nurses say you should drink 2-3 quarts the day off and day after. I find drinking more the day before and several days after has helped with the SEs. You can sleep or talk with others. Wear comfortable clothes and take a sweatshirt or something in case you get cold. My place has warm blankets but sometimes that is not enough. The IV is room temp vs body temp so it can make you chilled. The first time will be the longest as they take it slow to make sure you are tolerating well. My first time they sped up the Cytoxan and then had to slow it down as it was causing the tingly nose reaction. Now they know exactly how long each should take. For me it is @ 3 1/2 hrs but the first time took closer to 5. I meet with my MO before each tx so I bring my list of questions and take down any notes. Believe me, you are going to want to write things down they tell. Chemo brain or maybe just overload kicks in.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 07:49PM StayShiny wrote: Jenny, before this BC I took very little meds so I'm guessing the phenergans are for nausea or is it something that makes you tired? You could be "crashing" from the anti nausea meds that they gave you but they will flush out. I get more steroids and benadryl each time. The benadryl really makes me sleepy the first afternoon. Keep yourself hydrated with soups, fruit pops, fruit, water, whatever works for you. The day before, day of and couple days after are most important to stay hydrated. It will make you feel better. Try to get at least 64 oz a day. I found eating more protein and iron rich foods helped with my energy but the key is to eat. Many small, bland meals were easier for me every few hours. Eggs and fruit smoothies with protein powder have been some of my favorite go to foods. Also, try to get up and move some. As tired as you may be, you will feel better in the long run by moving. Take a short 5-10 min walk, hop on the exercise bike. Whatever you feel up to. Maybe even just getting outside for a breath of fresh air. You will feel better by Monday!! These symptoms won't last that long. I found day 3-5 to be my worse for fatigue. Need a few hour nap during the day. But then I was feeling the bounce coming back. Hope you feel better soon!

Posts.Content: May 23, 2012 03:38PM StayShiny wrote: Onvacation-sorry to hear about a funeral and your dad. Like you don't already have enough going on now! I will be thinking of you and your dad tomorrow. Be strong and stay positive. It will all go well. Melrose, I need to come to your house Sat! I have been craving more meat than usual. A grilled burger sounds yummy. I picked up some salmon burgers at Trader joes. Trying to be good with what I eat but may have to give in to the meat craving soon. Jenny, The port area shouldn't hurt for too many days. May feel a little funny when you turn your neck certain ways. Took me a little while to get used to it. I took 1,000mg of Tylenol for pain. They gave me a script pain killer that I had filled but never took. Hiker, I think I surprised a mother from my DD's class with my no hair. I haven't really made a big deal about my BC so not too many of the parents know. I showed up last week to the chess award ceremony with just a hat on. Didn't feel like putting on the wig. Then I saw her last night at the band concert and this time I had my wig on. She did a double take. Probably has figure out something is up now. Hair has thinned everywhere for me but can't say it is totally gone anywhere. My eyebrows and eyelashes seemed to thin after the 2nd tx. Thought I was really going to lose them big time like my head so ran out and bought an eyebrow pencil and new eyeliner. The eyeliner is a big help as there are some gaps in my lashes and the liner camouflages that. Can go with or without the eyebrow pencil. Hopefully the rest of you don't lose either. Hugs to all
